summary: This document is an email chain from September 2020 between Gary Bloxsome of Blackfords LLP, representing Prince Andrew, the Duke of York, and an Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York. The correspondence details negotiations over the Duke's potential cooperation with the U.S. investigation into Ghislaine Maxwell, with his lawyers offering a written witness statement and written answers but resisting a voluntary interview and limiting the scope of questions.

persons.name: Gary Bloxsome
persons.role: Partner at Blackfords LLP, legal representative for the Duke of York
persons.context: The primary author of the emails, negotiating the terms under which his client, the Duke of York, will provide information to the U.S. Attorney's office regarding the Ghislaine Maxwell investigation.

persons.name: Daniel Cundy
persons.context: A lawyer at the same firm as Gary Bloxsome, copied on the emails and involved in providing legal references to the U.S. Attorney's office.

persons.name: Jennifer Richardson
persons.context: An employee at Blackfords LLP who is copied on the email correspondence.

persons.name: The Duke of York
persons.role: Client of Blackfords LLP, subject/witness in U.S. investigation
persons.context: Prince Andrew, whose legal team is negotiating the conditions under which he will provide information about his associations with Ghislaine Maxwell and Jeffrey Epstein to U.S. prosecutors.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.role: Defendant in a pending criminal indictment
persons.context: The subject of the U.S. criminal investigation (1994-1997) for which the Duke of York's testimony is being sought.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.role: Deceased financier and associate of Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Mentioned in the context of the Duke of York's association with him, relevant to the investigation into Ghislaine Maxwell.

connections.description: Bloxsome is a partner at Blackfords LLP acting as legal counsel for the Duke of York, negotiating his cooperation with U.S. authorities.
The Duke is asked to provide a witness statement about his association with Ghislaine Maxwell, who is under indictment.
The Duke is asked to provide information about his knowledge of and association with Jeffrey Epstein.
Both are partners at Blackfords LLP working on the same case for their client, the Duke of York.

events.title: Conference call between legal teams
events.description: A conference held between the Duke of York's UK legal team and the U.S. Attorney's office, one of several held in July and August 2020.

locations: London, England (Blackfords LLP office at 15 Old Bailey, EC4M 7EF)
New York, NY, USA (Southern District of New York office at St. Andrew's Plaza, 10007)
Croydon, England (Blackfords LLP registered address at Hill House, 1 Mint Walk, CR0 1EA)
keyFacts: Prince Andrew's lawyers offered that he would provide a written witness statement and answer written questions relevant to the Ghislaine Maxwell indictment, but resisted a voluntary in-person or video interview with U.S. prosecutors.
The U.S. Attorney's office stated they regarded Prince Andrew not as a witness but as a 'subject' of their investigation, a point of contention with his legal team.

Prince Andrew's legal team sought to limit questioning to the period of the Maxwell indictment (1994-1997) and demanded strict confidentiality, preventing sharing with complainants or in civil matters.

The correspondence reveals a negotiation deadlock, with U.S. prosecutors interpreting the offer of written answers only as a refusal to participate in an interview or answer questions about events outside 1994-1997.
